1.title: 13th Amendment
1.subtitle: The 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, ratified in 1865 in the aftermath of the Civil War, abolished slavery in the United States.

2.title: Dr. Ernest Everett Just
2.subtitle: Dr. Ernest Just was a pioneering African American biologist, academic and science writer. Just's primary legacy is his recognition of the fundamental role of the cell surface in the development of organisms.

13.title: How we're priming some kids for college — and others for prison
13.subtitle: In the United States, two institutions guide teenagers on the journey to adulthood: college and prison. Sociologist Alice Goffman spent six years in a troubled Philadelphia neighborhood and saw first-hand how teenagers of African-American and Latino backgrounds are funneled down the path to prison — sometimes starting with relatively minor infractions. In an impassioned talk she asks, "Why are we offering only handcuffs and jail time?"

21.title: Justice for Julius Jones
21.subtitle: Julius Jones is on death row in Oklahoma, despite maintaining his innocence and compelling evidence that he was wrongfully convicted. Send an email to express your support of his release.

emailInfo.subject: Justice for Julius Jones
emailInfo.messageBody:
Dear Oklahoma Pardon & Parole Board members,

I strongly feel that Julius Darius Jones (# 270147) was wrongfully convicted of murder and sentenced to death in 2002. A crime for which he has always maintained his innocence.

Jones, a black 19 year old man, was arrested in 1999 for shooting white insurance executive Paul Scott Howell in Edmond, Oklahoma. At the time of his arrest, Julius was a successful athlete and honor student on scholarship at the University of Oklahoma.

Recently, new evidence of racial bias in the Jones’ case has been uncovered by the ABC documentary, “The Last Defense.”

One day after the documentary finale aired (7-25-18), the Oklahoma Criminal Court of Appeals released a document indicating they could take a look at the Jones’ case.

There are many factors that were overlooked and never presented during the Julius Jones trial.
1. Jones’ attorney during the trial was inexperienced by his own admission and this was his first death penalty case.
2. Several key pieces of evidence were never presented to the jury.
3. Tunnel vision set in and the police and prosecutor ignored evidence pointing to others as the shooter.
4. The court ignored an alleged racial statement made by one of the jurors
5. The jury judged Jones based on his race.
After viewing the recent ABC documentary, “The Last Defense,” I am even more convinced than ever of Julius’ innocence and that he should be given a new trial. I also ask that District Attorney David Prater release Julius Jones’ case files to his attorneys in order to promote public trust in both the criminal justice system and in Julius Jones’s case.

We all have all heard the phrase ‘beyond a shadow of doubt.’ To me, there is more than a shadow of doubt in this case.

Please, I ask that you do whatever is within your power to support Julius Jones’ Clemency Petition and see that this injustice – the wrongful conviction of Julius Jones – is overturned.

Thank you,
[Your Name]
[Your location]

22.title: African-American Heroism in the Military
22.subtitle: Dating all the way back to the American Revolution, African-Americans have played key roles in the history (and success) of the U.S. military. Profiled below are some notable African-Americans and their achievements, as well as milestones in the integration of African-Americans in the U.S. military.

22.title: Esusu
22.subtitle: Forbes Under 30 social entrepreneurs, Nigerian-born entrepreneur Wemimo and his business partner Goel co-founded Esusu in 2019. The mobile platform helps individuals mostly from marginalized communities save money, access capital and build credit.

22.title: Why Protests and Riots Work
22.subtitle: Riots are destructive, dangerous, and scary — but can lead to serious social reforms. To prevent more violent uprisings and protests, we need to take their causes seriously.

23.title: Constance Baker Motley: Judiciary’s Unsung Rights Hero
23.subtitle: Constance Baker Motley was an unlikely civil rights hero. An African American who grew up near Yale University, she did not personally experience overt racism until late in high school, and as a young person she was almost totally unaware of black history.

23.subtitle: Things actually got tougher for Black baseball players after Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier, as MLB teams followed racist quotas and the Negro Leagues died out. "Many talented Black players got phased out."

24.title: Afro Flow Yoga
24.subtitle:
With over 14 years of experience, Leslie Salmon Jones continues to pursue an active interdisciplinary career in health and dance in Boston and New York City. A Toronto native, Leslie received her B.A. in Dance and Health Studies at the State University of New York, and her Fitness Instructors Certification at New York University. She was a scholarship recipient at the esteemed Alvin Ailey Dance Theatre in New York City as well as the London Contemporary Dance School.

As a professional dancer, Leslie worked with known greats such as Judith Jameson, Bill T. Jones and Wynton Marsalis. At her studio in New York, she developed her own exercise program based on various techniques honed through working with her personal training clientele on a daily basis. Today she continues to divide her time between New York City and Boston.

Leslie has extensive experience in the fitness industry, including being a consultant for the New York Knicks healthy lifestyle clinic that teaches self-esteem to youth. She also served as a board member for the organization, Free Arts for Abused Kids, NYC. Today, she serves as a board member of the United Nations Association of New York

25.title: Hiram Rhodes Revels - Biography
25.subtitle: A freeman his entire life, Hiram Rhodes Revels was the first African American to serve in the U.S. Congress. With his moderate political orientation and oratorical skills honed from years as a preacher, Revels filled a vacant seat in the United States Senate in 1870.

LDF also defends the gains and protections won over the past 75 years of civil rights struggle and works to improve the quality and diversity of judicial and executive appointments.

26.title: Alaffia

Together, we’re cultivating beauty, equality and empowerment in West Africa and around the globe. Our women’s cooperatives in West Africa handcraft indigenous raw ingredients then the Alaffia team in Olympia, Washington creates the finished products. Alaffia returns the proceeds from the sale of these products to our communities to fund community empowerment and gender equality projects.

28.title: McBride Sisters Winery
28.subtitle: Since 2005, The McBride Sisters’ mission has become clear—to transform the industry, lead by example, and cultivate community, one delcious glass of wine, at a time.

products.name: McBride Sisters Collection Black Girl Magic 2018 California Merlot
products.description: This juicy and sensational wine is a classic Merlot, sophisticated for the wine connoisseur and delicious for the wine novices.

products.name: McBride Sisters Collection Black Girl Magic NV New Zealand Sparkling Brut
products.description: Your new favorite sparkling wine. Pop the bubbly for any celebration or for the days you want to feel extra fancy. You deserve it.

products.name: SHE CAN 4-Pack Sampler
products.description: Yes SHE CAN have it all! Enjoy our most popular sampler including one of each flavor. Four cans is the equivalent of two bottles of wine and an amazing value for these delicious wines and spritzers.

28.title: KAZMALEJE
28.subtitle: At KAZMALEJE (pronounced cosmology), we are dedicated to creating innovative, lifestyle-amplifying tools and accessories to improve our customers' hair care and beauty regimens.

products.name: KurlsPlus Paddle Comb
products.description: Our KurlsPlus Paddle Comb is great for detangling all hair types, lengths and thickness. It is the ultimate power tool that will allow you to detangle, blow dry, massage and style all in ONE!

products.name: KurlsPlus Pick
products.description: Our KurlsPlus Pick is great for short cuts or adding volume after a braid out, twist out or roller set. It's the ideal styling companion for travelers or on-the-go curlistas who need to refresh their hair throughout the day.

products.name: KurlsPlus Comb
products.description: Meet our KurlsPlus Comb. Our Comb is great for detangling hair of all lengths that is normal to thick in density with minimal stress on your hair whether wet or dry. It's also great for raking through heat styled curls to create a feathered look or detangling wigs/extensions without disrupting the curl pattern too much resulting in unwanted frizz.

29.title: Find Black-owned bookstores near you
29.subtitle: The African American Literature Book Club (AALBC.com) has put together a map of Blac-owned bookstores across the US. Find your nearest one here.

29.title: The Afro Gypsy
29.subtitle: I create jewelry and accessories that enhance the uniqueness of you; we like to call it Bohemian with an AFRO-tude! My work predominantly consist of leather and metalwork items. But, considering my love for the extraordinary, you may stumble upon many other new or vintage items that could steal your heart!

products.name: Unisex African Bead Bracelets paired with Lava or Wood Beads
products.description: African Bead Bracelets paired with Lava or Wood Beads. Sultry and handsome, these bracelets are all hand made with stretch cord.

products.name: Handmade Journal
products.description: Handmade journal covered in luxurious upcycled upholstery with a hand sewn leather trim. This 96-page journal is ready to hold your secrets and hear your dreams. 3.75" w × 6.7" h.

products.name: Large Amethyst Pendant Necklace
products.description: Hand wired Large Amethyst pendant necklace with 14K Antiqued GP chain and findings.

30.title: Alter Planning Co.
30.subtitle:
Alter Planning Co was founded by scottie., a young artist and entrepreneur who grew tired of looking for the perfect planner every year. She crafted each product to help fuel the creativity and productivity of those who used it. 

As an artist, scottie. has a deep understanding of the need for structure and wants to inspire more people to create routines and form in their life.

30.title: Juneteenth Challenges A Narrative About America’s History
30.subtitle: Juneteenth marks the day in 1865 when Union troops arrived in Galveston, Texas, and the enslaved people living there learned of their freedom — more than two years after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation. As such, the day tells a broader story of how emancipation was woefully delayed for Black people enslaved deep in the Confederacy.

31.title: Microaggressions Are A Big Deal: How To Talk Them Out And When To Walk Away
31.subtitle: Microaggressions are defined as the everyday, subtle, intentional — and oftentimes unintentional — interactions or behaviors that communicate some sort of bias toward historically marginalized groups. Learn more in this podcast from NPR.

31.title: Controversy over Confederate monuments is overdue
31.subtitle: As Confederate monuments and memorials are toppled across the United States, Stanford historian James T. Campbell says it is important to think historically not only about the past but also about our own time and what future generations might say about us.
